ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: learned grammar and translations skills at a fast pace
I learned all of Latin grammar (all of it!), and I also gained insight into Roman culture by reading primary sources! More than anything I gained a love of Latin that will carry me for a long time!
More latin grammar and skill including translation of real Latin. Learned subjunctives, more participles, supine, etc
I learned more about Latin grammar and looked into a bit of Latin prose, specifically by Petronius.
I developed all of the foundational skills to translate Latin including a strong understanding for grammar and an expansive vocabulary.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: grammar and vocabulary were easy to learn thanks to the course structure, but there were too many quizzes

I thought this course was run incredibly well! The textbook was good, the exercises were good, and it was taught with a lot of adaptability! Id love just a little more practice translating super long sentences, but in general, awesome!

Strengths: Instructor was amazing! Eleanor put so much time and effort into the class and always made handouts and passages for us to practice
Weakness: None
I think it was a good class!
I loved the format and the Professor.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: i would recommend this course to anyone interested in latin or the romance languages

Yes, I definitely recommend taking this course regardless of whether or not you are using it for your language requirement. It does have a moderately high workload because you are still learning how Latin works and how to translate sentences and texts. Still, the instruction and translation work is very engaging, and doing the translation exercises never feels like a burden. 

Both in this course and Latin 120, I was taught by graduate students from the Classics department. Both instructors I had are amazing and they care very much both about you as a person and how you feel learning the course material, going above and beyond in their teaching both inside and outside of class time. In Latin 120, once we moved on from the textbook to translating a Latin text, which for my class was Petronius's Satyricon, my instructor continued to provide the same level of support both inside and outside of class. She also allowed us to submit recommendations for which primary texts we wanted to translate and gave us samples of three texts so we could translate the samples before deciding as a class which text we wanted to continue with. This course was probably my favorite of all of the courses I took this semester. Every graduate student and Professor I have interacted with in the Classics department has been amazing. If you have the chance to take any courses in this department, I highly recommend it.
I would one hundred percent recommend this course to another student! It was taught well, and an awesome beginner language.
100% I love Latin and this class was fundamental in further skill development
Yes, if someone wants to learn Latin or more about grammar in general they should take this course.
